subCards.title: 6-year-old boy severely injured in pitbull attack, dog owner arrested
subCards.abstract: A six-year-old boy in Delhi's Prem Nagar area was severely injured after being attacked by a neighbour's Pitbull. The child was playing outside his home when the dog, owned by 50-year-old tailor Rajesh Pal of Vinay Enclave, suddenly charged at him. During the attack, the boy's right ear was bitten off, leaving him critically injured. Neighbours rushed to help the parents rescue the child, who was first taken to BSA Hospital in Rohini and then referred to Safdarjung Hospital for specialised treatment.

A parent of the deceased child stated, 'I request them to de-affiliate the school as 5000+ students are there already. The life is at risk.' subCards.title: Jalna Student Suicide: 13-Year-Old's Death Sparks Debate on School Harassment and Rising Cases
subCards.abstract: This special report covers the tragic death of a 13-year-old student in Jalna, Maharashtra, who died by suicide after jumping from her school building. The incident has brought national attention to the issue of student well-being, with the victim's father alleging mental torture by school teachers. The report contextualises this event with other recent cases in Jaipur and Delhi, highlighting a distressing trend. According to the report, 'the priority remains to ensure another bright mind is not lost to suicide'. It cites National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data, which shows student suicides increased from 8,423 in 2013 to 13,892 in 2023, a rise of about 65% in a decade. The programme raises the question of whether schools are solely responsible or if parents also have a role to play in preventing such tragedies.

cards.title: 5 most beautiful forests in India for every nature lover
cards.abstract: India is a diverse land with extraordinary biodiversity and some unique ecosystems. The forests in India are some of the most enchanting areas, greatly embedded with history and vibrant wildlife roaming freely in the lush greenery. Forests in India provide shelter to a lot of animals and bird species, and here tourists can also get a glimpse of the breathtaking beauty that the forests of India are.

slides.title: 5 most beautiful forests in India for every nature lover
slides.body:
India is a diverse land with extraordinary biodiversity and some unique ecosystems. The forests in India are some of the most enchanting areas, greatly embedded with history and vibrant wildlife roaming freely in the lush greenery. Forests in India provide shelter to a lot of animals and bird species, and here tourists can also get a glimpse of the breathtaking beauty that the forests of India are.

Let’s take a look at some of the most beautiful forests in India:

image.title: 5 most beautiful forests in India for every nature lover
image.caption:
India is a diverse land with extraordinary biodiversity and some unique ecosystems. The forests in India are some of the most enchanting areas, greatly embedded with history and vibrant wildlife roaming freely in the lush greenery. Forests in India provide shelter to a lot of animals and bird species, and here tourists can also get a glimpse of the breathtaking beauty that the forests of India are.

Let’s take a look at some of the most beautiful forests in India:

slides.title: Kanha National Park
slides.body: This national park is located in the Mandla and Balaghat districts of Madhya Pradesh. This is also one of the largest national parks in the country. This national park features dense sal and bamboo forests, open meadows, and clear streams that add to the beauty of the forest. This park is also a biodiversity hotspot with a wide variety of flora and fauna. One can spot animals such as chital, sambar, barasingha, gaur, Bengal tiger, Indian leopard, dhole, sloth bear, and Indian jackal. This national park also hosts around 300 species of birds and is also a major tiger reserve. The best time to visit this park is between October to June.

image.title: Kanha National Park
image.caption: This national park is located in the Mandla and Balaghat districts of Madhya Pradesh. This is also one of the largest national parks in the country. This national park features dense sal and bamboo forests, open meadows, and clear streams that add to the beauty of the forest. This park is also a biodiversity hotspot with a wide variety of flora and fauna. One can spot animals such as chital, sambar, barasingha, gaur, Bengal tiger, Indian leopard, dhole, sloth bear, and Indian jackal. This national park also hosts around 300 species of birds and is also a major tiger reserve. The best time to visit this park is between October to June.

slides.title: Sundarbans Mangrove Forest
slides.body: The largest mangrove forest in the world is located in West Bengal in the Ganges Delta, where the confluence of the Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna rivers forms on the Bay of Bengal. Some parts of the Sundarbans forest have also been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The dominant tree species found here are sundri (Heritiera fomes) and gewa (Excoecaria agallocha). This area also supports a rich biodiversity with 453 fauna species, which includes 290 bird, 120 fish, and other species. This area is also a critical habitat for the Bengal tiger and other threatened species. This mangrove forest is a treasure with rich biodiversity and natural disaster resilience, making it one of the most beautiful forests in India.

images.title: Jim Corbett National Park
images.caption: Located in the Nainital district of Uttarakhand, this is India’s first national park and is also a quite famous wildlife reserve. This national park is located in the foothills of the Himalayas and has diverse terrain which includes hills, grasslands, and lakes which also support great flora and fauna. It has a dense moist deciduous forest which consists of the sal tree, peepal, and mango trees and hosts 617 different species of plants and fauna. One can spot wildlife such as Bengal tigers, Asian elephants, leopards, sloth bears, and many other mammal species.

5 most beautiful forests in India for every nature lover
images.caption:
India is a diverse land with extraordinary biodiversity and some unique ecosystems. The forests in India are some of the most enchanting areas, greatly embedded with history and vibrant wildlife roaming freely in the lush greenery. Forests in India provide shelter to a lot of animals and bird species, and here tourists can also get a glimpse of the breathtaking beauty that the forests of India are.

Let’s take a look at some of the most beautiful forests in India:

images.title: Kanha National Park
images.caption: This national park is located in the Mandla and Balaghat districts of Madhya Pradesh. This is also one of the largest national parks in the country. This national park features dense sal and bamboo forests, open meadows, and clear streams that add to the beauty of the forest. This park is also a biodiversity hotspot with a wide variety of flora and fauna. One can spot animals such as chital, sambar, barasingha, gaur, Bengal tiger, Indian leopard, dhole, sloth bear, and Indian jackal. This national park also hosts around 300 species of birds and is also a major tiger reserve. The best time to visit this park is between October to June.

images.title: Sundarbans Mangrove Forest
images.caption: The largest mangrove forest in the world is located in West Bengal in the Ganges Delta, where the confluence of the Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna rivers forms on the Bay of Bengal. Some parts of the Sundarbans forest have also been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The dominant tree species found here are sundri (Heritiera fomes) and gewa (Excoecaria agallocha). This area also supports a rich biodiversity with 453 fauna species, which includes 290 bird, 120 fish, and other species. This area is also a critical habitat for the Bengal tiger and other threatened species. This mangrove forest is a treasure with rich biodiversity and natural disaster resilience, making it one of the most beautiful forests in India.

images.title: Jim Corbett National Park
images.caption: Located in the Nainital district of Uttarakhand, this is India’s first national park and is also a quite famous wildlife reserve. This national park is located in the foothills of the Himalayas and has diverse terrain which includes hills, grasslands, and lakes which also support great flora and fauna. It has a dense moist deciduous forest which consists of the sal tree, peepal, and mango trees and hosts 617 different species of plants and fauna. One can spot wildlife such as Bengal tigers, Asian elephants, leopards, sloth bears, and many other mammal species.

cards.title: Keerthy Suresh Says AI Morphing Has Become Scarier: 'I Never Posed Like This, Did I?'
cards.abstract: Actor Keerthy Suresh has once again raised concerns about the growing misuse of artificial intelligence, especially in the context of how it is being weaponised against women in the film industry. While promoting her upcoming action-drama Revolver Rita, she spoke at length about the issue during a podcast with Sudhir Srinivasan, reflecting on how AI-generated images have escalated the long-standing problem of morphing. Keerthy Suresh on misuse...
